title.narrative: 2.2 ACCESS TO Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: Output 2.2: The Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) sector at national and subnational levels have increased capacities and expand equitable and sustainable access to safe and affordable drinking water and sanitation and hygiene services., which contributes to Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: OUTCOME 2: Nigerians, especially women, girls and those in vulnerable situations in rural and urban settings have equitable and sustainable access to and use safe and affordable water supply, sanitation and hygiene practices in communities and institutions and live in an open defecation-free environment

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 2.2: The WASH sector at national and subnational levels have increased capacities and expand equitable and sustainableaccess to safe and affordable drinking water and sanitation and hygiene services.

description.narrative: There is a strategic shift by the WASH section from direct service delivery to more advocacy and sector influencing. However, UNICEF provides technical support to the government in designing and implementing climate-resilient WASH facilities for improved access to safe WASH services at the community and institutional levels. In the reporting year, 2 million people gained access to safe drinking water supply services by providing 2,655 water facilities in communities while 77,127 pupils in schools and 8,763 patients and caregivers in health care facilities accessed WASH services. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:22/12/2021
